questions.text: A 74-year-old person presents to the emergency department for evaluation of confusion. The patient’s partner states that the previous night the patient was acting “normal.” However, the patient’s partner says that this morning they found the patient sitting on the toilet and that the patient couldn’t remember their own name or where they were, so the partner called emergency services. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia for which they take amlodipine and tamsulosin. The patient drinks one to two glasses of wine at night. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 131/70 mmHg, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation is 98% on room air. The patient is currently oriented to self but not to place or year. The patient is asked to spell the word “world” backwards, but they are unable to do so. The patient is able to follow simple one-step commands, moves all extremities appropriately, and ambulates without difficulty. The patient’s abdomen is soft and mildly distended. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Further diagnostic testing is most likely to demonstrate which of the following findings?

choices.text: Head CT demonstrating microvascular ischemia and subcortical infarctions
MRI brain demonstrating diffuse cortical brain atrophy

questions.solution:
This patient presents with an abrupt change in cognitive function, disorientation, and attention, all of which are concerning for delirium. Among the most common causes of delirium is urinary tract infection, which will typically show a positive nitrite and bacteria on urinalysis.    

Delirium refers to an abrupt change in cognitive status secondary to an underlying organic condition; it is the most common cause of altered mental status in the inpatient setting. Delirium particularly affects elderly patients, and common causes include acute nervous system disorders or medical illness (e.g., urinary tract infection, pneumonia, sepsis) as well as medications (e.g., benzodiazepines, anticholinergics). Additional triggers include sleep deprivation, metabolic disturbance, and substance misuse or withdrawal.  

Clinical features include a waxing and waning mental status that acutely shifts from the patient’s baseline. These patients often demonstrate decreased attention, disorientation, as well as delusions or hallucinations. Diagnosis is primarily clinical but can be solicited with EEG monitoring, which will typically demonstrate diffuse background rhythm slowing.  

Option Analysis

✅ Nitrite positive urinalysis with 3+ bacteria :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Head CT demonstrating microvascular ischemia and subcortical infarctions:
Incorrect: Vascular dementia is characterized radiographically by recurrent subcortical infarctions. This form of dementia follows a stepwise decline in cognitive function. 
❌ MRI brain demonstrating diffuse cortical brain atrophy:
Incorrect: Diffuse cortical brain atrophy is observed in patients with Alzheimer disease, which presents as a gradual decline in cognitive function.  
❌ Head CT demonstrating ventricular expansion :
Incorrect: Normal pressure hydrocephalus manifests with ventricular expansion on CT imaging and presents with clinical features of gait apraxia, urinary retention, and cognitive dysfunction. This patient does not have evidence of gait dysfunction. 
❌ Elevated serum alcohol level :
Incorrect: Toxic/metabolic disturbance should always be considered in patients presenting with altered mental status. Alcohol withdrawal can often precipitate symptoms of delirium. Alcohol intoxication or withdrawal would be unlikely in this patient given the absence of slurred speech, ataxia, or motor disturbance.

questions.text: A 25-year-old graduate student comes to the physician for evaluation of excessive sleepiness over the past year. He is often sleepy during the day and frequently falls asleep during class. These episodes occur nearly daily and have been negatively affecting his grades. The patient goes to bed at 10 PM and wakes up at 7 AM. Last week, during an argument with his partner, the patient suddenly felt weak in the legs and collapsed onto the floor. The patient does not consume alcohol or recreational drugs. He has not experienced a loss of interest in his normal activities and does not have suicidal ideations. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following additional features is likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Urge to move the legs while trying to fall asleep
Decreased appetite and feelings of guilt

questions.solution:
This patient has been experiencing cataplexy (sudden muscle weakness) and excessive daytime sleepiness despite getting adequate rest at night. He likely has narcolepsy.

Narcolepsy is often caused by an autoimmune process that destroys nearly all the orexin-producing neurons. Orexin is vital to promoting wakefulness throughout the day. The lack of orexin results in four key symptoms:
 
  •  Excessive daytime sleepiness, despite adequate sleep at night, can progress to the point where patients can have brief sleep episodes with little warning at any time or place.  
  •  Cataplexy refers to sudden episodes of muscle weakness that can be triggered by strong positive or negative emotions (e.g., laughter, intense anger). Most often, cataplexy affects only the face and neck. However, severe episodes can lead to total body weakness or paralysis, causing the person to slump to the ground. 
  •  Sleep paralysis is the complete inability to move for a few seconds to minutes immediately after waking up or before falling asleep. During REM sleep, the voluntary muscles of the body are paralyzed; in narcolepsy, the loss of orexin leads to reduced REM latency and a rapid transition into REM sleep, which can manifest as sleep paralysis. 
  •  Vivid hallucinations may occur when falling asleep (hypnagogic hallucinations) or upon awakening (hypnopompic hallucinations). Commonly reported hallucinations include seeing a threatening stranger or animals in the bedroom. 

Option Analysis

✅ Vivid hallucinations while falling asleep   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ REM sleep without atonia   :
Incorrect: Loss of normal REM sleep atonia is a feature of REM sleep behavior disorder, which is a parasomnia wherein patients act out their dreams. The condition can occur independently or be a hallmark of various neurodegenerative disorders (e.g., Parkinson disease, Lewy body dementia, multiple system atrophy). This patient, who is presenting with cataplexy as well as excessive daytime sleepiness despite getting adequate rest at night, likely has another underlying diagnosis.   
❌ Urge to move the legs while trying to fall asleep   :
Incorrect: Restless leg syndrome is a sleep movement disorder wherein patients have an uncomfortable sensation and urge to move their legs while trying to fall asleep. This patient, who is presenting with cataplexy as well as excessive daytime sleepiness despite getting adequate rest at night, likely has another underlying diagnosis.   
❌ Interruptions in breathing while sleeping   :
Incorrect: Interruptions in breathing while sleeping is suggestive of sleep apnea. Although patients with sleep apnea may also experience excessive daytime sleepiness, this patient’s episode of cataplexy makes narcolepsy a more likely diagnosis.   
❌ Decreased appetite and feelings of guilt   :
Incorrect: Decreased appetite and feelings of guilt are symptoms of major depressive disorder (MDD). This patient does not have other hallmark features of MDD, such as anhedonia (loss of interest) or suicidal ideation. Furthermore, this patient has excessive daytime sleepiness despite adequate sleep and cataplexy, which are more suggestive of another underlying diagnosis.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to the physician for evaluation of excessive sleepiness over the past 3 months. He is often sleepy during the day and has spontaneously fallen asleep in class. The symptoms occur nearly daily and have been negatively affecting his grades. He usually goes to bed at 10 PM and wakes up at 8 AM. Last week, during an upsetting conversation about his grades with his parents, the patient suddenly felt weak in the legs and collapsed onto the floor. He also describes “hearing whispering noises and seeing animals wandering in the room” as he is falling asleep. The patient does not drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is noncontributory. Autoimmune destruction of which of the following regions of the hypothalamus is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has been experiencing excessive daytime sleepiness, hallucinations while falling asleep, and cataplexy (sudden muscle weakness). He likely has narcolepsy, which can arise due to the destruction of lateral hypothalamic neurons.

The lateral hypothalamus contains a group of neurons that produce the neurotransmitter orexin (hypocretin) while an individual is awake. Orexins have excitatory effects that promote wakefulness. For unknown reasons, in individuals with narcolepsy, an autoimmune process destroys nearly all the orexin-producing neurons during puberty. As a result, there is a lack of orexin, which results in four key symptoms:
 
  •  Excessive daytime sleepiness, despite adequate sleep at night, can progress to the point where patients can have brief sleep episodes with little warning at any time or place.  
  •  Cataplexy refers to sudden episodes of muscle weakness that can be triggered by strong positive or negative emotions (e.g., laughter, intense anger). Most often, cataplexy affects only the face and neck. However, severe episodes can lead to total body weakness or paralysis, causing the person to slump to the ground. 
  •  Sleep paralysis is the complete inability to move for a few seconds to minutes immediately after waking up or before falling asleep. During REM sleep, the voluntary muscles of the body are paralyzed; in narcolepsy, the loss of orexin leads to reduced REM latency and a rapid transition into REM sleep, which can manifest as sleep paralysis.  
  • Vivid hallucinations may occur when falling asleep (hypnagogic hallucinations) or upon awakening (hypnopompic hallucinations). Commonly reported hallucinations include seeing a threatening stranger or animals in the bedroom. 
Although narcolepsy cannot be cured, treatment options exist to improve the patient’s quality of life. Lifestyle modifications, such as having a strict and regular sleeping schedule with brief naps throughout the day, can help. Some individuals may benefit from treatment with stimulants like dextroamphetamine or modafinil to prevent daytime sleepiness. Sodium oxybate, also known as gamma-hydroxybutyrate (GHB), can be used at nighttime to improve sleep quality.  

Option Analysis

✅ Lateral hypothalamus   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Suprachiasmatic nucleus   :
Incorrect: The suprachiasmatic nucleus is involved in regulating the circadian rhythm. Although dysregulation of this nucleus can result in excessive daytime sleepiness, this patient’s adequate amount of nightly sleep and sudden episodes of muscle weakness (cataplexy) are more suggestive of a different underlying condition.   
❌ Supraoptic nucleus   :
Incorrect: The supraoptic nucleus contains vasopressin-synthesizing neurons. In patients with a specific type of diabetes insipidus, there is destruction of these vasopressin-secreting neurons, resulting in excessive urination. This patient’s excessive daytime sleepiness suggests a different underlying condition.   
❌ Preoptic nucleus   :
Incorrect: The preoptic nucleus contains GnRH-releasing neurons. In the developing embryo, the neurons migrate from the olfactory pit to the preoptic area of the hypothalamus. However, in patients with Kallman syndrome, there is a failure of this migration, resulting in delayed puberty and anosmia. In contrast, this patient’s excessive daytime sleepiness is more suggestive of a different underlying condition.   
❌ Ventromedial nucleus   :
Incorrect: The ventromedial nucleus controls satiety. Therefore, destruction (such as from a craniopharyngioma) of this region of the hypothalamus can result in hyperphagia. In contrast, this patient’s excessive daytime sleepiness is more suggestive of a different underlying condition.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by their son for evaluation of confusion. The patient's son reports that he went to the patient’s apartment to check on the patient and found her lying on the ground. The son explains that “She couldn’t tell me what happened, so I called 911.” The patient’s past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, and a recent left femoral neck fracture. The patient’s current medications include lisinopril, metformin, atorvastatin, ibuprofen, and acetaminophen. The patient is currently employed as a lawyer and has been working at home since the fracture. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 104/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 107/70 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 93% on room air. Initial assessment demonstrates an elderly female who appears confused. The patient states, “What you are trying to do to me here is illegal. You are trying to lock me up and throw away the key!” Physical examination reveals a left lower extremity in a cast with adequate capillary refill and without other signs of injury or trauma. The patient is not physically abusive and follows directions given by the physician and nurses. A chest X-ray is demonstrated below.  Which of the following best describes the etiology of this patient’s confusion?


Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an abrupt change in cognitive function, disorientation, inattention, and delusions, all of which are concerning for delirium. In addition, the clinical presentation and chest X-ray are concerning for pneumonia: the likely trigger for her altered mental status. The most important first step in addressing delirium in a patient is treating the underlying cause (e.g. antibiotics).      

Delirium refers to an abrupt change in cognitive status secondary to an underlying organic condition; it is the most common cause of altered mental status in the inpatient setting. Delirium particularly affects elderly patients, and common causes include acute nervous system disorders or medical illness (e.g., pneumonia, urinary tract infection, sepsis) as well as medications (such as benzodiazepines and those with anticholinergic properties). Additional triggers include sleep deprivation, metabolic disturbances, and substance misuse or withdrawal.    

Management of delirium, after addressing the underlying cause, includes supportive measures, medications, and restraints (only as a last resort). Supportive measures include reorienting the patient, removing distractions or sensory disturbances (e.g. turning off lights), and limiting polypharmacy. If the patient’s delirium persists and they become agitated, antipsychotic medications, such as haloperidol, may be administered. Lastly, if a patient poses a threat to themselves or others despite the aforementioned therapies, physical restraints may be necessary.  

Option Analysis

✅ Delirium:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Septic emboli :
Incorrect: This patient has no evidence of focal neurologic deficits, making septic emboli unlikely. Instead, this patient has evidence of delirium secondary to an underlying pneumonia.  
❌ Beta-amyloid plaques:
Incorrect: Diffuse cortical brain atrophy is observed in patients with Alzheimer disease, which presents as a gradual decline in cognitive function. Instead, this patient has evidence of delirium secondary to an underlying pneumonia.  
❌  Ischemic stroke :
Incorrect: This patient has no evidence of focal neurologic deficits, making an ischemic stroke unlikely. Instead, this patient has evidence of delirium secondary to an underlying pneumonia.  
❌ Alcohol toxicity:
Incorrect: Toxic/metabolic disturbance should always be considered in patients presenting with altered mental status. Alcohol withdrawal can often precipitate symptoms of delirium. However, alcohol intoxication or withdrawal is unlikely in this patient given absence of slurred speech, ataxia, or motor disturbance.
